title: 14¬† Strings
text:
14.1 Introduction
So far, you‚Äôve used a bunch of strings without learning much about the details. Now it‚Äôs time to dive into them, learn what makes strings tick, and master some of the powerful string manipulation tools you have at your disposal.
We‚Äôll begin with the details of creating strings and character vectors. You‚Äôll then dive into creating strings from data, then the opposite: extracting strings from data. We‚Äôll then discuss tools that work with individual letters. The chapter finishes with functions that work with individual letters and a brief discussion of where your expectations from English might steer you wrong when working with other languages.
We‚Äôll keep working with strings in the next chapter, where you‚Äôll learn more about the power of regular expressions.

title: 14¬† Strings
text:
14.1.1 Prerequisites
In this chapter, we‚Äôll use functions from the stringr package, which is part of the core tidyverse. We‚Äôll also use the babynames data since it provides some fun strings to manipulate.

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
You can quickly tell when you‚Äôre using a stringr function because all stringr functions start with str_. This is particularly useful if you use RStudio because typing str_ will trigger autocomplete, allowing you to jog your memory of the available functions.

title: 14¬† Strings
text:
14.2 Creating a string
We‚Äôve created strings in passing earlier in the book but didn‚Äôt discuss the details. Firstly, you can create a string using either single quotes (') or double quotes ("). There‚Äôs no difference in behavior between the two, so in the interests of consistency, the tidyverse style guide recommends using ", unless the string contains multiple ".

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
If you forget to close a quote, you‚Äôll see +, the continuation prompt:
> "This is a string without a closing quote
+ 
+ 
+ HELP I'M STUCK IN A STRING
If this happens to you and you can‚Äôt figure out which quote to close, press Escape to cancel and try again.

14.2.1 Escapes
To include a literal single or double quote in a string, you can use \ to ‚Äúescape‚Äù it:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
So if you want to include a literal backslash in your string, you‚Äôll need to escape it: "\\":

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
Beware that the printed representation of a string is not the same as the string itself because the printed representation shows the escapes (in other words, when you print a string, you can copy and paste the output to recreate that string). To see the raw contents of the string, use str_view()1:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.

14.2.2 Raw strings
Creating a string with multiple quotes or backslashes gets confusing quickly. To illustrate the problem, let‚Äôs create a string that contains the contents of the code block where we define the double_quote and single_quote variables:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
That‚Äôs a lot of backslashes! (This is sometimes called leaning toothpick syndrome.) To eliminate the escaping, you can instead use a raw string2:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
A raw string usually starts with r"( and finishes with )". But if your string contains )" you can instead use r"[]" or r"{}", and if that‚Äôs still not enough, you can insert any number of dashes to make the opening and closing pairs unique, e.g., r"--()--", r"---()---", etc. Raw strings are flexible enough to handle any text.

14.2.3 Other special characters
As well as \", \', and \\, there are a handful of other special characters that may come in handy. The most common are \n, a new line, and \t, tab. You‚Äôll also sometimes see strings containing Unicode escapes that start with \u or \U. This is a way of writing non-English characters that work on all systems. You can see the complete list of other special characters in ?Quotes.

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
Note that str_view() uses curly braces for tabs to make them easier to spot3. One of the challenges of working with text is that there‚Äôs a variety of ways that white space can end up in the text, so this background helps you recognize that something strange is going on.

14.2.4 Exercises

Create the string in your R session and print it. What happens to the special ‚Äú\u00a0‚Äù? How does str_view() display it? Can you do a little googling to figure out what this special character is?

14.3 Creating many strings from data
Now that you‚Äôve learned the basics of creating a string or two by ‚Äúhand‚Äù, we‚Äôll go into the details of creating strings from other strings. This will help you solve the common problem where you have some text you wrote that you want to combine with strings from a data frame. For example, you might combine ‚ÄúHello‚Äù with a name variable to create a greeting. We‚Äôll show you how to do this with str_c() and str_glue() and how you can use them with mutate(). That naturally raises the question of what stringr functions you might use with summarize(), so we‚Äôll finish this section with a discussion of str_flatten(), which is a summary function for strings.

14.3.1 str_c()

str_c() takes any number of vectors as arguments and returns a character vector:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
str_c() is very similar to the base paste0(), but is designed to be used with mutate() by obeying the usual tidyverse rules for recycling and propagating missing values:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
If you want missing values to display in another way, use coalesce() to replace them. Depending on what you want, you might use it either inside or outside of str_c():

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.

14.3.2 str_glue()

If you are mixing many fixed and variable strings with str_c(), you‚Äôll notice that you type a lot of "s, making it hard to see the overall goal of the code. An alternative approach is provided by the glue package via str_glue()4. You give it a single string that has a special feature: anything inside {} will be evaluated like it‚Äôs outside of the quotes:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
As you can see, str_glue() currently converts missing values to the string "NA", unfortunately making it inconsistent with str_c().
You also might wonder what happens if you need to include a regular { or } in your string. You‚Äôre on the right track if you guess you‚Äôll need to escape it somehow. The trick is that glue uses a slightly different escaping technique: instead of prefixing with special character like \, you double up the special characters:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.

14.3.3 str_flatten()

str_c() and str_glue() work well with mutate() because their output is the same length as their inputs. What if you want a function that works well with summarize(), i.e.¬†something that always returns a single string? That‚Äôs the job of str_flatten()5: it takes a character vector and combines each element of the vector into a single string:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
This makes it work well with summarize():

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.

title: 14¬† Strings
text:
14.4 Extracting data from strings
It‚Äôs very common for multiple variables to be crammed together into a single string. In this section, you‚Äôll learn how to use four tidyr functions to extract them:

df |> separate_longer_delim(col, delim)
df |> separate_longer_position(col, width)
df |> separate_wider_delim(col, delim, names)
df |> separate_wider_position(col, widths)

If you look closely, you can see there‚Äôs a common pattern here: separate_, then longer or wider, then _, then by delim or position. That‚Äôs because these four functions are composed of two simpler primitives:

Just like with pivot_longer() and pivot_wider(), _longer functions make the input data frame longer by creating new rows and _wider functions make the input data frame wider by generating new columns.

delim splits up a string with a delimiter like ", " or " "; position splits at specified widths, like c(3, 5, 2).

We‚Äôll return to the last member of this family, separate_wider_regex(), in Chapter 15. It‚Äôs the most flexible of the wider functions, but you need to know something about regular expressions before you can use it.
The following two sections will give you the basic idea behind these separate functions, first separating into rows (which is a little simpler) and then separating into columns. We‚Äôll finish off by discussing the tools that the wider functions give you to diagnose problems.

14.4.1 Separating into rows
Separating a string into rows tends to be most useful when the number of components varies from row to row. The most common case is requiring separate_longer_delim() to split based on a delimiter:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
It‚Äôs rarer to see separate_longer_position() in the wild, but some older datasets do use a very compact format where each character is used to record a value:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.

14.4.2 Separating into columns
Separating a string into columns tends to be most useful when there are a fixed number of components in each string, and you want to spread them into columns. They are slightly more complicated than their longer equivalents because you need to name the columns. For example, in this following dataset, x is made up of a code, an edition number, and a year, separated by ".". To use separate_wider_delim(), we supply the delimiter and the names in two arguments:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
If a specific piece is not useful you can use an NA name to omit it from the results:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
separate_wider_position() works a little differently because you typically want to specify the width of each column. So you give it a named integer vector, where the name gives the name of the new column, and the value is the number of characters it occupies. You can omit values from the output by not naming them:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.

14.4.3 Diagnosing widening problems
separate_wider_delim()6 requires a fixed and known set of columns. What happens if some of the rows don‚Äôt have the expected number of pieces? There are two possible problems, too few or too many pieces, so separate_wider_delim() provides two arguments to help: too_few and too_many. Let‚Äôs first look at the too_few case with the following sample dataset:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
You‚Äôll notice that we get an error, but the error gives us some suggestions on how you might proceed. Let‚Äôs start by debugging the problem:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
When you use the debug mode, you get three extra columns added to the output: x_ok, x_pieces, and x_remainder (if you separate a variable with a different name, you‚Äôll get a different prefix). Here, x_ok lets you quickly find the inputs that failed:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
x_pieces tells us how many pieces were found, compared to the expected 3 (the length of names). x_remainder isn‚Äôt useful when there are too few pieces, but we‚Äôll see it again shortly.
Sometimes looking at this debugging information will reveal a problem with your delimiter strategy or suggest that you need to do more preprocessing before separating. In that case, fix the problem upstream and make sure to remove too_few = "debug" to ensure that new problems become errors.
In other cases, you may want to fill in the missing pieces with NAs and move on. That‚Äôs the job of too_few = "align_start" and too_few = "align_end" which allow you to control where the NAs should go:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
The same principles apply if you have too many pieces:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
But now, when we debug the result, you can see the purpose of x_remainder:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
You have a slightly different set of options for handling too many pieces: you can either silently ‚Äúdrop‚Äù any additional pieces or ‚Äúmerge‚Äù them all into the final column:

14.5 Letters
In this section, we‚Äôll introduce you to functions that allow you to work with the individual letters within a string. You‚Äôll learn how to find the length of a string, extract substrings, and handle long strings in plots and tables.

14.5.1 Length
str_length() tells you the number of letters in the string:

You can extract parts of a string using str_sub(string, start, end), where start and end are the positions where the substring should start and end. The start and end arguments are inclusive, so the length of the returned string will be end - start + 1:

title: 14¬† Strings
text:
14.6 Non-English text
So far, we‚Äôve focused on English language text which is particularly easy to work with for two reasons. Firstly, the English alphabet is relatively simple: there are just 26 letters. Secondly (and maybe more importantly), the computing infrastructure we use today was predominantly designed by English speakers. Unfortunately, we don‚Äôt have room for a full treatment of non-English languages. Still, we wanted to draw your attention to some of the biggest challenges you might encounter: encoding, letter variations, and locale-dependent functions.

14.6.1 Encoding
When working with non-English text, the first challenge is often the encoding. To understand what‚Äôs going on, we need to dive into how computers represent strings. In R, we can get at the underlying representation of a string using charToRaw():

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
Each of these six hexadecimal numbers represents one letter: 48 is H, 61 is a, and so on. The mapping from hexadecimal number to character is called the encoding, and in this case, the encoding is called ASCII. ASCII does a great job of representing English characters because it‚Äôs the American Standard Code for Information Interchange.
Things aren‚Äôt so easy for languages other than English. In the early days of computing, there were many competing standards for encoding non-English characters. For example, there were two different encodings for Europe: Latin1 (aka ISO-8859-1) was used for Western European languages, and Latin2 (aka ISO-8859-2) was used for Central European languages. In Latin1, the byte b1 is ‚Äú¬±‚Äù, but in Latin2, it‚Äôs ‚ÄúƒÖ‚Äù! Fortunately, today there is one standard that is supported almost everywhere: UTF-8. UTF-8 can encode just about every character used by humans today and many extra symbols like emojis.
readr uses UTF-8 everywhere. This is a good default but will fail for data produced by older systems that don‚Äôt use UTF-8. If this happens, your strings will look weird when you print them. Sometimes just one or two characters might be messed up; other times, you‚Äôll get complete gibberish. For example here are two inline CSVs with unusual encodings8:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
To read these correctly, you specify the encoding via the locale argument:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
How do you find the correct encoding? If you‚Äôre lucky, it‚Äôll be included somewhere in the data documentation. Unfortunately, that‚Äôs rarely the case, so readr provides guess_encoding() to help you figure it out. It‚Äôs not foolproof and works better when you have lots of text (unlike here), but it‚Äôs a reasonable place to start. Expect to try a few different encodings before you find the right one.
Encodings are a rich and complex topic; we‚Äôve only scratched the surface here. If you‚Äôd like to learn more, we recommend reading the detailed explanation at http://kunststube.net/encoding/.

14.6.2 Letter variations
Working in languages with accents poses a significant challenge when determining the position of letters (e.g., with str_length() and str_sub()) as accented letters might be encoded as a single individual character (e.g., √º) or as two characters by combining an unaccented letter (e.g., u) with a diacritic mark (e.g., ¬®). For example, this code shows two ways of representing √º that look identical:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
But both strings differ in length, and their first characters are different:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
Finally, note that a comparison of these strings with == interprets these strings as different, while the handy str_equal() function in stringr recognizes that both have the same appearance:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.

14.6.3 Locale-dependent functions
Finally, there are a handful of stringr functions whose behavior depends on your locale. A locale is similar to a language but includes an optional region specifier to handle regional variations within a language. A locale is specified by a lower-case language abbreviation, optionally followed by a _ and an upper-case region identifier. For example, ‚Äúen‚Äù is English, ‚Äúen_GB‚Äù is British English, and ‚Äúen_US‚Äù is American English. If you don‚Äôt already know the code for your language, Wikipedia has a good list, and you can see which are supported in stringr by looking at stringi::stri_locale_list().
Base R string functions automatically use the locale set by your operating system. This means that base R string functions do what you expect for your language, but your code might work differently if you share it with someone who lives in a different country. To avoid this problem, stringr defaults to English rules by using the ‚Äúen‚Äù locale and requires you to specify the locale argument to override it. Fortunately, there are two sets of functions where the locale really matters: changing case and sorting.
The rules for changing cases differ among languages. For example, Turkish has two i‚Äôs: with and without a dot. Since they‚Äôre two distinct letters, they‚Äôre capitalized differently:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
Sorting strings depends on the order of the alphabet, and the order of the alphabet is not the same in every language9! Here‚Äôs an example: in Czech, ‚Äúch‚Äù is a compound letter that appears after h in the alphabet.

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
This also comes up when sorting strings with dplyr::arrange(), which is why it also has a locale argument.

14.7 Summary
In this chapter, you‚Äôve learned about some of the power of the stringr package: how to create, combine, and extract strings, and about some of the challenges you might face with non-English strings. Now it‚Äôs time to learn one of the most important and powerful tools for working with strings: regular expressions. Regular expressions are a very concise but very expressive language for describing patterns within strings and are the topic of the next chapter.

title: 15¬† Regular expressions
text:
15.1 Introduction
In Chapter 14, you learned a whole bunch of useful functions for working with strings. This chapter will focus on functions that use regular expressions, a concise and powerful language for describing patterns within strings. The term ‚Äúregular expression‚Äù is a bit of a mouthful, so most people abbreviate it to ‚Äúregex‚Äù1 or ‚Äúregexp‚Äù.
The chapter starts with the basics of regular expressions and the most useful stringr functions for data analysis. We‚Äôll then expand your knowledge of patterns and cover seven important new topics (escaping, anchoring, character classes, shorthand classes, quantifiers, precedence, and grouping). Next, we‚Äôll talk about some of the other types of patterns that stringr functions can work with and the various ‚Äúflags‚Äù that allow you to tweak the operation of regular expressions. We‚Äôll finish with a survey of other places in the tidyverse and base R where you might use regexes.

title: 15¬† Regular expressions
text:
15.1.1 Prerequisites
In this chapter, we‚Äôll use regular expression functions from stringr and tidyr, both core members of the tidyverse, as well as data from the babynames package.

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
Through this chapter, we‚Äôll use a mix of very simple inline examples so you can get the basic idea, the baby names data, and three character vectors from stringr:

fruit contains the names of 80 fruits.
words contains 980 common English words.
sentences contains 720 short sentences.

title: 15¬† Regular expressions
text:
15.2 Pattern basics
We‚Äôll use str_view() to learn how regex patterns work. We used str_view() in the last chapter to better understand a string vs.¬†its printed representation, and now we‚Äôll use it with its second argument, a regular expression. When this is supplied, str_view() will show only the elements of the string vector that match, surrounding each match with <>, and, where possible, highlighting the match in blue.
The simplest patterns consist of letters and numbers which match those characters exactly:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
Letters and numbers match exactly and are called literal characters. Most punctuation characters, like ., +, *, [, ], and ?, have special meanings2 and are called metacharacters. For example, . will match any character3, so "a." will match any string that contains an ‚Äúa‚Äù followed by another character :

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
Or we could find all the fruits that contain an ‚Äúa‚Äù, followed by three letters, followed by an ‚Äúe‚Äù:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
Quantifiers control how many times a pattern can match:

? makes a pattern optional (i.e.¬†it matches 0 or 1 times)
+ lets a pattern repeat (i.e.¬†it matches at least once)
* lets a pattern be optional or repeat (i.e.¬†it matches any number of times, including 0).


Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
Character classes are defined by [] and let you match a set of characters, e.g., [abcd] matches ‚Äúa‚Äù, ‚Äúb‚Äù, ‚Äúc‚Äù, or ‚Äúd‚Äù. You can also invert the match by starting with ^: [^abcd] matches anything except ‚Äúa‚Äù, ‚Äúb‚Äù, ‚Äúc‚Äù, or ‚Äúd‚Äù. We can use this idea to find the words containing an ‚Äúx‚Äù surrounded by vowels, or a ‚Äúy‚Äù surrounded by consonants:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
You can use alternation, |, to pick between one or more alternative patterns. For example, the following patterns look for fruits containing ‚Äúapple‚Äù, ‚Äúmelon‚Äù, or ‚Äúnut‚Äù, or a repeated vowel.

Regular expressions are very compact and use a lot of punctuation characters, so they can seem overwhelming and hard to read at first. Don‚Äôt worry; you‚Äôll get better with practice, and simple patterns will soon become second nature. Let‚Äôs kick off that process by practicing with some useful stringr functions.

15.3 Key functions
Now that you‚Äôve got the basics of regular expressions under your belt, let‚Äôs use them with some stringr and tidyr functions. In the following section, you‚Äôll learn how to detect the presence or absence of a match, how to count the number of matches, how to replace a match with fixed text, and how to extract text using a pattern.

15.3.1 Detect matches
str_detect() returns a logical vector that is TRUE if the pattern matches an element of the character vector and FALSE otherwise:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
Since str_detect() returns a logical vector of the same length as the initial vector, it pairs well with filter(). For example, this code finds all the most popular names containing a lower-case ‚Äúx‚Äù:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
We can also use str_detect() with summarize() by pairing it with sum() or mean(): sum(str_detect(x, pattern)) tells you the number of observations that match and mean(str_detect(x, pattern)) tells you the proportion that match. For example, the following snippet computes and visualizes the proportion of baby names4 that contain ‚Äúx‚Äù, broken down by year. It looks like they‚Äôve radically increased in popularity lately!

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
There are two functions that are closely related to str_detect(): str_subset() and str_which(). str_subset() returns a character vector containing only the strings that match. str_which() returns an integer vector giving the positions of the strings that match.


15.3.2 Count matches
The next step up in complexity from str_detect() is str_count(): rather than a true or false, it tells you how many matches there are in each string.

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
Note that each match starts at the end of the previous match, i.e.¬†regex matches never overlap. For example, in "abababa", how many times will the pattern "aba" match? Regular expressions say two, not three:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
It‚Äôs natural to use str_count() with mutate(). The following example uses str_count() with character classes to count the number of vowels and consonants in each name.

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
If you look closely, you‚Äôll notice that there‚Äôs something off with our calculations: ‚ÄúAaban‚Äù contains three ‚Äúa‚Äùs, but our summary reports only two vowels. That‚Äôs because regular expressions are case sensitive. There are three ways we could fix this:

Add the upper case vowels to the character class: str_count(name, "[aeiouAEIOU]").
Tell the regular expression to ignore case: str_count(name, regex("[aeiou]", ignore_case = TRUE)). We‚Äôll talk about more in Section 15.5.1.
Use str_to_lower() to convert the names to lower case: str_count(str_to_lower(name), "[aeiou]").

This variety of approaches is pretty typical when working with strings ‚Äî there are often multiple ways to reach your goal, either by making your pattern more complicated or by doing some preprocessing on your string. If you get stuck trying one approach, it can often be useful to switch gears and tackle the problem from a different perspective.
In this case, since we‚Äôre applying two functions to the name, I think it‚Äôs easier to transform it first:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.


15.3.3 Replace values
As well as detecting and counting matches, we can also modify them with str_replace() and str_replace_all(). str_replace() replaces the first match, and as the name suggests, str_replace_all() replaces all matches.

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
str_remove() and str_remove_all() are handy shortcuts for str_replace(x, pattern, ""):

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
These functions are naturally paired with mutate() when doing data cleaning, and you‚Äôll often apply them repeatedly to peel off layers of inconsistent formatting.


15.3.4 Extract variables
The last function we‚Äôll discuss uses regular expressions to extract data out of one column into one or more new columns: separate_wider_regex(). It‚Äôs a peer of the separate_wider_position() and separate_wider_delim() functions that you learned about in Section 14.4.2. These functions live in tidyr because they operate on (columns of) data frames, rather than individual vectors.
Let‚Äôs create a simple dataset to show how it works. Here we have some data derived from babynames where we have the name, gender, and age of a bunch of people in a rather weird format5:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
To extract this data using separate_wider_regex() we just need to construct a sequence of regular expressions that match each piece. If we want the contents of that piece to appear in the output, we give it a name:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
If the match fails, you can use too_few = "debug" to figure out what went wrong, just like separate_wider_delim() and separate_wider_position().


15.3.5 Exercises

What baby name has the most vowels? What name has the highest proportion of vowels? (Hint: what is the denominator?)
Replace all forward slashes in "a/b/c/d/e" with backslashes. What happens if you attempt to undo the transformation by replacing all backslashes with forward slashes? (We‚Äôll discuss the problem very soon.)

title: 15¬† Regular expressions
text:
15.4 Pattern details
Now that you understand the basics of the pattern language and how to use it with some stringr and tidyr functions, it‚Äôs time to dig into more of the details. First, we‚Äôll start with escaping, which allows you to match metacharacters that would otherwise be treated specially. Next, you‚Äôll learn about anchors which allow you to match the start or end of the string. Then, you‚Äôll learn more about character classes and their shortcuts which allow you to match any character from a set. Next, you‚Äôll learn the final details of quantifiers which control how many times a pattern can match. Then, we have to cover the important (but complex) topic of operator precedence and parentheses. And we‚Äôll finish off with some details of grouping components of the pattern.
The terms we use here are the technical names for each component. They‚Äôre not always the most evocative of their purpose, but it‚Äôs very helpful to know the correct terms if you later want to Google for more details.

15.4.1 Escaping
In order to match a literal ., you need an escape which tells the regular expression to match metacharacters6 literally. Like strings, regexps use the backslash for escaping. So, to match a ., you need the regexp \.. Unfortunately this creates a problem. We use strings to represent regular expressions, and \ is also used as an escape symbol in strings. So to create the regular expression \. we need the string "\\.", as the following example shows.

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
In this book, we‚Äôll usually write regular expression without quotes, like \.. If we need to emphasize what you‚Äôll actually type, we‚Äôll surround it with quotes and add extra escapes, like "\\.".
If \ is used as an escape character in regular expressions, how do you match a literal \? Well, you need to escape it, creating the regular expression \\. To create that regular expression, you need to use a string, which also needs to escape \. That means to match a literal \ you need to write "\\\\" ‚Äî you need four backslashes to match one!

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
Alternatively, you might find it easier to use the raw strings you learned about in Section 14.2.2). That lets you avoid one layer of escaping:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
If you‚Äôre trying to match a literal ., $, |, *, +, ?, {, }, (, ), there‚Äôs an alternative to using a backslash escape: you can use a character class: [.], [$], [|], ‚Ä¶ all match the literal values.

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.


15.4.2 Anchors
By default, regular expressions will match any part of a string. If you want to match at the start or end you need to anchor the regular expression using ^ to match the start or $ to match the end:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
It‚Äôs tempting to think that $ should match the start of a string, because that‚Äôs how we write dollar amounts, but that‚Äôs not what regular expressions want.
To force a regular expression to match only the full string, anchor it with both ^ and $:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
You can also match the boundary between words (i.e.¬†the start or end of a word) with \b. This can be particularly useful when using RStudio‚Äôs find and replace tool. For example, if to find all uses of sum(), you can search for \bsum\b to avoid matching summarize, summary, rowsum and so on:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
When used alone, anchors will produce a zero-width match:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
This helps you understand what happens when you replace a standalone anchor:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.


15.4.3 Character classes
A character class, or character set, allows you to match any character in a set. As we discussed above, you can construct your own sets with [], where [abc] matches ‚Äúa‚Äù, ‚Äúb‚Äù, or ‚Äúc‚Äù and [^abc] matches any character except ‚Äúa‚Äù, ‚Äúb‚Äù, or ‚Äúc‚Äù. Apart from ^ there are two other characters that have special meaning inside of []:

- defines a range, e.g., [a-z] matches any lower case letter and [0-9] matches any number.
\ escapes special characters, so [\^\-\]] matches ^, -, or ].

Here are few examples:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
Some character classes are used so commonly that they get their own shortcut. You‚Äôve already seen ., which matches any character apart from a newline. There are three other particularly useful pairs7:

\d matches any digit;
\D matches anything that isn‚Äôt a digit.
\s matches any whitespace (e.g., space, tab, newline);
\S matches anything that isn‚Äôt whitespace.
\w matches any ‚Äúword‚Äù character, i.e.¬†letters and numbers;
\W matches any ‚Äúnon-word‚Äù character.

The following code demonstrates the six shortcuts with a selection of letters, numbers, and punctuation characters.

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.


15.4.4 Quantifiers
Quantifiers control how many times a pattern matches. In Section 15.2 you learned about ? (0 or 1 matches), + (1 or more matches), and * (0 or more matches). For example, colou?r will match American or British spelling, \d+ will match one or more digits, and \s? will optionally match a single item of whitespace. You can also specify the number of matches precisely with {}:

{n} matches exactly n times.
{n,} matches at least n times.
{n,m} matches between n and m times.



15.4.5 Operator precedence and parentheses
What does ab+ match? Does it match ‚Äúa‚Äù followed by one or more ‚Äúb‚Äùs, or does it match ‚Äúab‚Äù repeated any number of times? What does ^a|b$ match? Does it match the complete string a or the complete string b, or does it match a string starting with a or a string ending with b?
The answer to these questions is determined by operator precedence, similar to the PEMDAS or BEDMAS rules you might have learned in school. You know that a + b * c is equivalent to a + (b * c) not (a + b) * c because * has higher precedence and + has lower precedence: you compute * before +.
Similarly, regular expressions have their own precedence rules: quantifiers have high precedence and alternation has low precedence which means that ab+ is equivalent to a(b+), and ^a|b$ is equivalent to (^a)|(b$). Just like with algebra, you can use parentheses to override the usual order. But unlike algebra you‚Äôre unlikely to remember the precedence rules for regexes, so feel free to use parentheses liberally.


15.4.6 Grouping and capturing
As well as overriding operator precedence, parentheses have another important effect: they create capturing groups that allow you to use sub-components of the match.
The first way to use a capturing group is to refer back to it within a match with back reference: \1 refers to the match contained in the first parenthesis, \2 in the second parenthesis, and so on. For example, the following pattern finds all fruits that have a repeated pair of letters:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
And this one finds all words that start and end with the same pair of letters:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
You can also use back references in str_replace(). For example, this code switches the order of the second and third words in sentences:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
If you want to extract the matches for each group you can use str_match(). But str_match() returns a matrix, so it‚Äôs not particularly easy to work with8:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
You could convert to a tibble and name the columns:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
But then you‚Äôve basically recreated your own version of separate_wider_regex(). Indeed, behind the scenes, separate_wider_regex() converts your vector of patterns to a single regex that uses grouping to capture the named components.
Occasionally, you‚Äôll want to use parentheses without creating matching groups. You can create a non-capturing group with (?:).

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.


15.4.7 Exercises

How would you match the literal string "'\? How about "$^$"?
Explain why each of these patterns don‚Äôt match a \: "\", "\\", "\\\".

Have seven letters or more.
Contain a vowel-consonant pair.
Contain at least two vowel-consonant pairs in a row.

Try and make the shortest possible regex!
Switch the first and last letters in words. Which of those strings are still words?

text:
15.5 Pattern control
It‚Äôs possible to exercise extra control over the details of the match by using a pattern object instead of just a string. This allows you to control the so called regex flags and match various types of fixed strings, as described below.

15.5.1 Regex flags
There are a number of settings that can be used to control the details of the regexp. These settings are often called flags in other programming languages. In stringr, you can use these by wrapping the pattern in a call to regex(). The most useful flag is probably ignore_case = TRUE because it allows characters to match either their uppercase or lowercase forms:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
If you‚Äôre doing a lot of work with multiline strings (i.e.¬†strings that contain \n), dotalland multiline may also be useful:

dotall = TRUE lets . match everything, including \n:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
multiline = TRUE makes ^ and $ match the start and end of each line rather than the start and end of the complete string:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.

Finally, if you‚Äôre writing a complicated regular expression and you‚Äôre worried you might not understand it in the future, you might try comments = TRUE. It tweaks the pattern language to ignore spaces and new lines, as well as everything after #. This allows you to use comments and whitespace to make complex regular expressions more understandable9, as in the following example:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
If you‚Äôre using comments and want to match a space, newline, or #, you‚Äôll need to escape it with \.


15.5.2 Fixed matches
You can opt-out of the regular expression rules by using fixed():

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
fixed() also gives you the ability to ignore case:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
If you‚Äôre working with non-English text, you will probably want coll() instead of fixed(), as it implements the full rules for capitalization as used by the locale you specify. See Section 14.6 for more details on locales.

text:
15.6 Practice
To put these ideas into practice we‚Äôll solve a few semi-authentic problems next. We‚Äôll discuss three general techniques:

checking your work by creating simple positive and negative controls
combining regular expressions with Boolean algebra
creating complex patterns using string manipulation


15.6.1 Check your work
First, let‚Äôs find all sentences that start with ‚ÄúThe‚Äù. Using the ^ anchor alone is not enough:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
Because that pattern also matches sentences starting with words like They or These. We need to make sure that the ‚Äúe‚Äù is the last letter in the word, which we can do by adding a word boundary:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
What about finding all sentences that begin with a pronoun?

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
A quick inspection of the results shows that we‚Äôre getting some spurious matches. That‚Äôs because we‚Äôve forgotten to use parentheses:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
You might wonder how you might spot such a mistake if it didn‚Äôt occur in the first few matches. A good technique is to create a few positive and negative matches and use them to test that your pattern works as expected:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
It‚Äôs typically much easier to come up with good positive examples than negative examples, because it takes a while before you‚Äôre good enough with regular expressions to predict where your weaknesses are. Nevertheless, they‚Äôre still useful: as you work on the problem you can slowly accumulate a collection of your mistakes, ensuring that you never make the same mistake twice.


15.6.2 Boolean operations
Imagine we want to find words that only contain consonants. One technique is to create a character class that contains all letters except for the vowels ([^aeiou]), then allow that to match any number of letters ([^aeiou]+), then force it to match the whole string by anchoring to the beginning and the end (^[^aeiou]+$):

But you can make this problem a bit easier by flipping the problem around. Instead of looking for words that contain only consonants, we could look for words that don‚Äôt contain any vowels:

For example, imagine if you want to find all words that contain ‚Äúa‚Äù and ‚Äúb‚Äù. There‚Äôs no ‚Äúand‚Äù operator built in to regular expressions so we have to tackle it by looking for all words that contain an ‚Äúa‚Äù followed by a ‚Äúb‚Äù, or a ‚Äúb‚Äù followed by an ‚Äúa‚Äù:

15.6.4 Exercises

title: 15¬† Regular expressions
text:
15.7 Regular expressions in other places
Just like in the stringr and tidyr functions, there are many other places in R where you can use regular expressions. The following sections describe some other useful functions in the wider tidyverse and base R.

15.7.1 tidyverse
There are three other particularly useful places where you might want to use a regular expressions

matches(pattern) will select all variables whose name matches the supplied pattern. It‚Äôs a ‚Äútidyselect‚Äù function that you can use anywhere in any tidyverse function that selects variables (e.g., select(), rename_with() and across()).
pivot_longer()'s names_pattern argument takes a vector of regular expressions, just like separate_wider_regex(). It‚Äôs useful when extracting data out of variable names with a complex structure
The delim argument in separate_longer_delim() and separate_wider_delim() usually matches a fixed string, but you can use regex() to make it match a pattern. This is useful, for example, if you want to match a comma that is optionally followed by a space, i.e.¬†regex(", ?").



15.7.2 Base R
apropos(pattern) searches all objects available from the global environment that match the given pattern. This is useful if you can‚Äôt quite remember the name of a function:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
list.files(path, pattern) lists all files in path that match a regular expression pattern. For example, you can find all the R Markdown files in the current directory with:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
It‚Äôs worth noting that the pattern language used by base R is very slightly different to that used by stringr. That‚Äôs because stringr is built on top of the stringi package, which is in turn built on top of the ICU engine, whereas base R functions use either the TRE engine or the PCRE engine, depending on whether or not you‚Äôve set perl = TRUE. Fortunately, the basics of regular expressions are so well established that you‚Äôll encounter few variations when working with the patterns you‚Äôll learn in this book. You only need to be aware of the difference when you start to rely on advanced features like complex Unicode character ranges or special features that use the (?‚Ä¶) syntax.

title: 15¬† Regular expressions
text:
15.8 Summary
With every punctuation character potentially overloaded with meaning, regular expressions are one of the most compact languages out there. They‚Äôre definitely confusing at first but as you train your eyes to read them and your brain to understand them, you unlock a powerful skill that you can use in R and in many other places.
In this chapter, you‚Äôve started your journey to become a regular expression master by learning the most useful stringr functions and the most important components of the regular expression language. And there are plenty of resources to learn more.
A good place to start is vignette("regular-expressions", package = "stringr"): it documents the full set of syntax supported by stringr. Another useful reference is https://www.regular-expressions.info/. It‚Äôs not R specific, but you can use it to learn about the most advanced features of regexes and how they work under the hood.
It‚Äôs also good to know that stringr is implemented on top of the stringi package by Marek Gagolewski. If you‚Äôre struggling to find a function that does what you need in stringr, don‚Äôt be afraid to look in stringi. You‚Äôll find stringi very easy to pick up because it follows many of the the same conventions as stringr.
In the next chapter, we‚Äôll talk about a data structure closely related to strings: factors. Factors are used to represent categorical data in R, i.e.¬†data with a fixed and known set of possible values identified by a vector of strings.

title: 16¬† Factors
text:
16.1 Introduction
Factors are used for categorical variables, variables that have a fixed and known set of possible values. They are also useful when you want to display character vectors in a non-alphabetical order.
We‚Äôll start by motivating why factors are needed for data analysis1 and how you can create them with factor(). We‚Äôll then introduce you to the gss_cat dataset which contains a bunch of categorical variables to experiment with. You‚Äôll then use that dataset to practice modifying the order and values of factors, before we finish up with a discussion of ordered factors.

title: 16¬† Factors
text:
16.1.1 Prerequisites
Base R provides some basic tools for creating and manipulating factors. We‚Äôll supplement these with the forcats package, which is part of the core tidyverse. It provides tools for dealing with categorical variables (and it‚Äôs an anagram of factors!) using a wide range of helpers for working with factors.

title: 16¬† Factors
text:
16.2 Factor basics
Imagine that you have a variable that records month:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
Using a string to record this variable has two problems:

16.3 General Social Survey
For the rest of this chapter, we‚Äôre going to use forcats::gss_cat. It‚Äôs a sample of data from the General Social Survey, a long-running US survey conducted by the independent research organization NORC at the University of Chicago. The survey has thousands of questions, so in gss_cat Hadley selected a handful that will illustrate some common challenges you‚Äôll encounter when working with factors.

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
(Remember, since this dataset is provided by a package, you can get more information about the variables with ?gss_cat.)
When factors are stored in a tibble, you can‚Äôt see their levels so easily. One way to view them is with count():

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
When working with factors, the two most common operations are changing the order of the levels, and changing the values of the levels. Those operations are described in the sections below.

16.3.1 Exercises

text:
16.4 Modifying factor order
It‚Äôs often useful to change the order of the factor levels in a visualization. For example, imagine you want to explore the average number of hours spent watching TV per day across religions:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
It is hard to read this plot because there‚Äôs no overall pattern. We can improve it by reordering the levels of relig using fct_reorder(). fct_reorder() takes three arguments:

.f, the factor whose levels you want to modify.
.x, a numeric vector that you want to use to reorder the levels.
Optionally, .fun, a function that‚Äôs used if there are multiple values of .x for each value of .f. The default value is median.


Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
Reordering religion makes it much easier to see that people in the ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt know‚Äù category watch much more TV, and Hinduism & Other Eastern religions watch much less.
As you start making more complicated transformations, we recommend moving them out of aes() and into a separate mutate() step. For example, you could rewrite the plot above as:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
What if we create a similar plot looking at how average age varies across reported income level?

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
Here, arbitrarily reordering the levels isn‚Äôt a good idea! That‚Äôs because rincome already has a principled order that we shouldn‚Äôt mess with. Reserve fct_reorder() for factors whose levels are arbitrarily ordered.
However, it does make sense to pull ‚ÄúNot applicable‚Äù to the front with the other special levels. You can use fct_relevel(). It takes a factor, .f, and then any number of levels that you want to move to the front of the line.

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
Why do you think the average age for ‚ÄúNot applicable‚Äù is so high?
Another type of reordering is useful when you are coloring the lines on a plot. fct_reorder2(.f, .x, .y) reorders the factor .f by the .y values associated with the largest .x values. This makes the plot easier to read because the colors of the line at the far right of the plot will line up with the legend.

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
Finally, for bar plots, you can use fct_infreq() to order levels in decreasing frequency: this is the simplest type of reordering because it doesn‚Äôt need any extra variables. Combine it with fct_rev() if you want them in increasing frequency so that in the bar plot largest values are on the right, not the left.

16.5 Modifying factor levels
More powerful than changing the orders of the levels is changing their values. This allows you to clarify labels for publication, and collapse levels for high-level displays. The most general and powerful tool is fct_recode(). It allows you to recode, or change, the value of each level. For example, take the partyid variable from the gss_cat data frame:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
The levels are terse and inconsistent. Let‚Äôs tweak them to be longer and use a parallel construction. Like most rename and recoding functions in the tidyverse, the new values go on the left and the old values go on the right:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
fct_recode() will leave the levels that aren‚Äôt explicitly mentioned as is, and will warn you if you accidentally refer to a level that doesn‚Äôt exist.
To combine groups, you can assign multiple old levels to the same new level:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
Use this technique with care: if you group together categories that are truly different you will end up with misleading results.
If you want to collapse a lot of levels, fct_collapse() is a useful variant of fct_recode(). For each new variable, you can provide a vector of old levels:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
Sometimes you just want to lump together the small groups to make a plot or table simpler. That‚Äôs the job of the fct_lump_*() family of functions. fct_lump_lowfreq() is a simple starting point that progressively lumps the smallest groups categories into ‚ÄúOther‚Äù, always keeping ‚ÄúOther‚Äù as the smallest category.

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
In this case it‚Äôs not very helpful: it is true that the majority of Americans in this survey are Protestant, but we‚Äôd probably like to see some more details! Instead, we can use the fct_lump_n() to specify that we want exactly 10 groups:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
Read the documentation to learn about fct_lump_min() and fct_lump_prop() which are useful in other cases.

16.5.1 Exercises

How have the proportions of people identifying as Democrat, Republican, and Independent changed over time?
How could you collapse rincome into a small set of categories?
Notice there are 9 groups (excluding other) in the fct_lump example above. Why not 10? (Hint: type ?fct_lump, and find the default for the argument other_level is ‚ÄúOther‚Äù.)

title: 16¬† Factors
text:
16.6 Ordered factors
Before we go on, there‚Äôs a special type of factor that needs to be mentioned briefly: ordered factors. Ordered factors, created with ordered(), imply a strict ordering and equal distance between levels: the first level is ‚Äúless than‚Äù the second level by the same amount that the second level is ‚Äúless than‚Äù the third level, and so on. You can recognize them when printing because they use < between the factor levels:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
In practice, ordered() factors behave very similarly to regular factors. There are only two places where you might notice different behavior:

If you map an ordered factor to color or fill in ggplot2, it will default to scale_color_viridis()/scale_fill_viridis(), a color scale that implies a ranking.
If you use an ordered function in a linear model, it will use ‚Äúpolygonal contrasts‚Äù. These are mildly useful, but you are unlikely to have heard of them unless you have a PhD in Statistics, and even then you probably don‚Äôt routinely interpret them. If you want to learn more, we recommend vignette("contrasts", package = "faux") by Lisa DeBruine.

Given the arguable utility of these differences, we don‚Äôt generally recommend using ordered factors.

title: 16¬† Factors
text:
16.7 Summary
This chapter introduced you to the handy forcats package for working with factors, introducing you to the most commonly used functions. forcats contains a wide range of other helpers that we didn‚Äôt have space to discuss here, so whenever you‚Äôre facing a factor analysis challenge that you haven‚Äôt encountered before, I highly recommend skimming the reference index to see if there‚Äôs a canned function that can help solve your problem.
If you want to learn more about factors after reading this chapter, we recommend reading Amelia McNamara and Nicholas Horton‚Äôs paper, Wrangling categorical data in R. This paper lays out some of the history discussed in stringsAsFactors: An unauthorized biography and stringsAsFactors = <sigh>, and compares the tidy approaches to categorical data outlined in this book with base R methods. An early version of the paper helped motivate and scope the forcats package; thanks Amelia & Nick!
In the next chapter we‚Äôll switch gears to start learning about dates and times in R. Dates and times seem deceptively simple, but as you‚Äôll soon see, the more you learn about them, the more complex they seem to get!

title: 17¬† Dates and times
text:
17.1 Introduction
This chapter will show you how to work with dates and times in R. At first glance, dates and times seem simple. You use them all the time in your regular life, and they don‚Äôt seem to cause much confusion. However, the more you learn about dates and times, the more complicated they seem to get!
To warm up think about how many days there are in a year, and how many hours there are in a day. You probably remembered that most years have 365 days, but leap years have 366. Do you know the full rule for determining if a year is a leap year1? The number of hours in a day is a little less obvious: most days have 24 hours, but in places that use daylight saving time (DST), one day each year has 23 hours and another has 25.
Dates and times are hard because they have to reconcile two physical phenomena (the rotation of the Earth and its orbit around the sun) with a whole raft of geopolitical phenomena including months, time zones, and DST. This chapter won‚Äôt teach you every last detail about dates and times, but it will give you a solid grounding of practical skills that will help you with common data analysis challenges.
We‚Äôll begin by showing you how to create date-times from various inputs, and then once you‚Äôve got a date-time, how you can extract components like year, month, and day. We‚Äôll then dive into the tricky topic of working with time spans, which come in a variety of flavors depending on what you‚Äôre trying to do. We‚Äôll conclude with a brief discussion of the additional challenges posed by time zones.

title: 17¬† Dates and times
text:
17.1.1 Prerequisites
This chapter will focus on the lubridate package, which makes it easier to work with dates and times in R. As of the latest tidyverse release, lubridate is part of core tidyverse. We will also need nycflights13 for practice data.

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.

title: 17¬† Dates and times
text:
17.2 Creating date/times
There are three types of date/time data that refer to an instant in time:

A date. Tibbles print this as <date>.
A time within a day. Tibbles print this as <time>.
A date-time is a date plus a time: it uniquely identifies an instant in time (typically to the nearest second). Tibbles print this as <dttm>. Base R calls these POSIXct, but that doesn‚Äôt exactly trip off the tongue.

In this chapter we are going to focus on dates and date-times as R doesn‚Äôt have a native class for storing times. If you need one, you can use the hms package.
You should always use the simplest possible data type that works for your needs. That means if you can use a date instead of a date-time, you should. Date-times are substantially more complicated because of the need to handle time zones, which we‚Äôll come back to at the end of the chapter.
To get the current date or date-time you can use today() or now():

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
Otherwise, the following sections describe the four ways you‚Äôre likely to create a date/time:

While reading a file with readr.
From a string.
From individual date-time components.
From an existing date/time object.


17.2.1 During import
If your CSV contains an ISO8601 date or date-time, you don‚Äôt need to do anything; readr will automatically recognize it:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
If you haven‚Äôt heard of ISO8601 before, it‚Äôs an international standard2 for writing dates where the components of a date are organized from biggest to smallest separated by -. For example, in ISO8601 May 3 2022 is 2022-05-03. ISO8601 dates can also include times, where hour, minute, and second are separated by :, and the date and time components are separated by either a T or a space. For example, you could write 4:26pm on May 3 2022 as either 2022-05-03 16:26 or 2022-05-03T16:26.
For other date-time formats, you‚Äôll need to use col_types plus col_date() or col_datetime() along with a date-time format. The date-time format used by readr is a standard used across many programming languages, describing a date component with a % followed by a single character. For example, %Y-%m-%d specifies a date that‚Äôs a year, -, month (as number) -, day. Table Table¬†17.1 lists all the options.

text:
17.3 Date-time components
Now that you know how to get date-time data into R‚Äôs date-time data structures, let‚Äôs explore what you can do with them. This section will focus on the accessor functions that let you get and set individual components. The next section will look at how arithmetic works with date-times.

17.3.1 Getting components
You can pull out individual parts of the date with the accessor functions year(), month(), mday() (day of the month), yday() (day of the year), wday() (day of the week), hour(), minute(), and second(). These are effectively the opposites of make_datetime().

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
For month() and wday() you can set label = TRUE to return the abbreviated name of the month or day of the week. Set abbr = FALSE to return the full name.

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
We can use wday() to see that more flights depart during the week than on the weekend:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
We can also look at the average departure delay by minute within the hour. There‚Äôs an interesting pattern: flights leaving in minutes 20-30 and 50-60 have much lower delays than the rest of the hour!

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
Interestingly, if we look at the scheduled departure time we don‚Äôt see such a strong pattern:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
So why do we see that pattern with the actual departure times? Well, like much data collected by humans, there‚Äôs a strong bias towards flights leaving at ‚Äúnice‚Äù departure times, as ?fig-human-rounding shows. Always be alert for this sort of pattern whenever you work with data that involves human judgement!

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.


17.3.2 Rounding
An alternative approach to plotting individual components is to round the date to a nearby unit of time, with floor_date(), round_date(), and ceiling_date(). Each function takes a vector of dates to adjust and then the name of the unit to round down (floor), round up (ceiling), or round to. This, for example, allows us to plot the number of flights per week:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.

title: 17¬† Dates and times
text:
17.4 Time spans
Next you‚Äôll learn about how arithmetic with dates works, including subtraction, addition, and division. Along the way, you‚Äôll learn about three important classes that represent time spans:

Durations, which represent an exact number of seconds.
Periods, which represent human units like weeks and months.
Intervals, which represent a starting and ending point.

How do you pick between duration, periods, and intervals? As always, pick the simplest data structure that solves your problem. If you only care about physical time, use a duration; if you need to add human times, use a period; if you need to figure out how long a span is in human units, use an interval.

17.4.1 Durations
In R, when you subtract two dates, you get a difftime object:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
A difftime class object records a time span of seconds, minutes, hours, days, or weeks. This ambiguity can make difftimes a little painful to work with, so lubridate provides an alternative which always uses seconds: the duration.

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
Durations come with a bunch of convenient constructors:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
Durations always record the time span in seconds. Larger units are created by converting minutes, hours, days, weeks, and years to seconds: 60 seconds in a minute, 60 minutes in an hour, 24 hours in a day, and 7 days in a week. Larger time units are more problematic. A year uses the ‚Äúaverage‚Äù number of days in a year, i.e.¬†365.25. There‚Äôs no way to convert a month to a duration, because there‚Äôs just too much variation.
You can add and multiply durations:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
You can add and subtract durations to and from days:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
However, because durations represent an exact number of seconds, sometimes you might get an unexpected result:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
Why is one day after 1am March 8, 2am March 9? If you look carefully at the date you might also notice that the time zones have changed. March 8 only has 23 hours because it‚Äôs when DST starts, so if we add a full days worth of seconds we end up with a different time.


17.4.2 Periods
To solve this problem, lubridate provides periods. Periods are time spans but don‚Äôt have a fixed length in seconds, instead they work with ‚Äúhuman‚Äù times, like days and months. That allows them to work in a more intuitive way:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
Like durations, periods can be created with a number of friendly constructor functions.

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
You can add and multiply periods:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
And of course, add them to dates. Compared to durations, periods are more likely to do what you expect:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
Let‚Äôs use periods to fix an oddity related to our flight dates. Some planes appear to have arrived at their destination before they departed from New York City.

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
These are overnight flights. We used the same date information for both the departure and the arrival times, but these flights arrived on the following day. We can fix this by adding days(1) to the arrival time of each overnight flight.

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
Now all of our flights obey the laws of physics.

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.


17.4.3 Intervals
What does dyears(1) / ddays(365) return? It‚Äôs not quite one, because dyears() is defined as the number of seconds per average year, which is 365.25 days.
What does years(1) / days(1) return? Well, if the year was 2015 it should return 365, but if it was 2016, it should return 366! There‚Äôs not quite enough information for lubridate to give a single clear answer. What it does instead is give an estimate:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
If you want a more accurate measurement, you‚Äôll have to use an interval. An interval is a pair of starting and ending date times, or you can think of it as a duration with a starting point.
You can create an interval by writing start %--% end:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
You could then divide it by days() to find out how many days fit in the year:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.

title: 17¬† Dates and times
text:
17.5 Time zones
Time zones are an enormously complicated topic because of their interaction with geopolitical entities. Fortunately we don‚Äôt need to dig into all the details as they‚Äôre not all important for data analysis, but there are a few challenges we‚Äôll need to tackle head on.

The first challenge is that everyday names of time zones tend to be ambiguous. For example, if you‚Äôre American you‚Äôre probably familiar with EST, or Eastern Standard Time. However, both Australia and Canada also have EST! To avoid confusion, R uses the international standard IANA time zones. These use a consistent naming scheme {area}/{location}, typically in the form {continent}/{city} or {ocean}/{city}. Examples include ‚ÄúAmerica/New_York‚Äù, ‚ÄúEurope/Paris‚Äù, and ‚ÄúPacific/Auckland‚Äù.
You might wonder why the time zone uses a city, when typically you think of time zones as associated with a country or region within a country. This is because the IANA database has to record decades worth of time zone rules. Over the course of decades, countries change names (or break apart) fairly frequently, but city names tend to stay the same. Another problem is that the name needs to reflect not only the current behavior, but also the complete history. For example, there are time zones for both ‚ÄúAmerica/New_York‚Äù and ‚ÄúAmerica/Detroit‚Äù. These cities both currently use Eastern Standard Time but in 1969-1972 Michigan (the state in which Detroit is located), did not follow DST, so it needs a different name. It‚Äôs worth reading the raw time zone database (available at https://www.iana.org/time-zones) just to read some of these stories!
You can find out what R thinks your current time zone is with Sys.timezone():

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
(If R doesn‚Äôt know, you‚Äôll get an NA.)

title: 17¬† Dates and times
text:
17.6 Summary
This chapter has introduced you to the tools that lubridate provides to help you work with date-time data. Working with dates and times can seem harder than necessary, but hopefully this chapter has helped you see why ‚Äî date-times are more complex than they seem at first glance, and handling every possible situation adds complexity. Even if your data never crosses a day light savings boundary or involves a leap year, the functions need to be able to handle it.
The next chapter gives a round up of missing values. You‚Äôve seen them in a few places and have no doubt encounter in your own analysis, and it‚Äôs now time to provide a grab bag of useful techniques for dealing with them.
